bibl.title: Biography of Walter Reed, by Elizabeth S. Kosslow, [19--]

div1.p: Kosslow writes a succinct but vivid account of Walter Reed's life, dealing with his work on typhoid and yellow fever.

div1.head: Biography of Walter Reed, by Elizabeth S. Kosslow, [19--]
div1.opener:
From R. F. Nelson, Director of Publicity, Virginia State Chamber
of Commerce, Richmond, Va.
BY ELIZABETH S. KOSSLOW....
div1.p:
Gloucester, Va., July 00--Despairing at ever inspiring the
citizens of Gloucester County, Virginia with the necessary con-
fidence in his medical skill because he could not raise a decent
crop of whiskers, the badge of his profession, Dr. Walter Reed,
17, slipped away from his picturesque birthplace, Belroi, and
became an international hero.

The little weather-beaten hut, long hidden by weeds,
today is on the way to restoration, according to the Virginia
State Chamber of Commerce, and within six weeks the world will
find an easy path to the tiny home of the man who earned the
title of “The Father of Modern Public Health”, made the world
free of the scourge of Yellow Fever and taught it how to combat
typhoid successfully. He earned his title by playing the leading
role in lengthening the span of life from thirty-eight years in
1890 to fifty-eight in 1926, a gift of twenty years to every man!

Restoring Belroi was the idea of Dr. Clarence Porter-
Jones, a local specialist whose zeal in interesting medical
societies in the cause quickly brought material results, and the
Walter Reed Medical Society of Virginia was empowered to effect
the restoration. Years of vacancy and inattention had brought the
historic house to its ebb, and immediate restoration was impera-
tive.

This is only part of the big national program to per-
petuate the memory of Reed; the medical word is now at work creat-
ing a $1,000,000 fund for the establishment at the University of
Virginia medical school of a research chair, where the experiments
and work of the famous Virginian can be carried still farther.

Reed's eventful life captivates the imagination of every
member of his profession. Born in the humblest of homes in 1865,
the son of a Methodist Circuit Rider, he struggled bitterly to
prepare himself for the University of Virginia, was graduated
a doctor of medicine at the age of 17 and entered Bellevue
Medical College, New York. He left there to become an assistant
surgeon and first lieutenant in the United States Army in 1875,
serving at obscure posts in Arizona, Nebraska, and Dakota, where
he distinguished himself for his devotion to the poorest dwellers
about him.

Here Reed began showing the sterner qualities which made
him famous by such tasks as riding four days through a blizzard
to set the broken leg of a child living in a dugout, spending
sleepless nights to save some choking child from diptheria.

Assigned to Baltimore, the young doctor quickly began spending
his spare time in the great laboratories of Johns Hopkins Univer-
sity, where he made his most important investigations, working
untiringly and blazing the trail for modern public health. He so
well succeeded that he was ordered to Washington and given the
chair of bacteriology in the new Medical School, where he attracted
world attention.

During the Spanish War his study of typhoid fever established
the fact that to become infected it is necessary to swallow the
live germs through food or drink, and that the house fly is the
most potent carrier. One of the strangest things in history was
the fact that this report was not published until several years
went by. This caused a loss to the British Army alone of thousands
of lives during the Boer War.

Dr. Reed's life came swiftly to its dramatic climax in 1900
when he was sent to Cuba to Study Yellow Fever. He had as his
- 3 -
assistant Dr. James W. Carroll, Dr. Jesse W. Lazear and A.
Adrimonte, the latter a Cuban, immune to the disease. Reed first
noticed that strict sanitation had nothing to do with the number
of cases of Yellow Fever occuring at the various posts, suggest-
ing to him that an insect was the carrier.

What insect? no mention of the Finlay theory- He saw a peculiar mosquito biting a Yellow
Fever patient; a study of the mosquito later proved that after
biting the patient, a period of twelve days elapsed before the in-
sect became infectious; its ability to transmit the disease, how-
ever, lasted through life.

The work then reached a dramatic point. On August 27, Dr.
Carroll allowed one infected mosquito to bite him. Four days
later he became ill with the disease and barely escaped death. It
left him with a heart lesion which caused his death seven years
later. Dr. Lazear, failing to become infected when bitten by the
same mosquito, exposed himself again, became ill and died, the
first martyr.

Tests were resumed in December, when two of Dr. Reed's
colleagues, Dr. W. C. Gorgas and John Guiteras made similar ex-
periments. Of twenty-five volunteers accepted for their excellent
health, all contracted the disease, and due to efficient care,
only four died; a doctor, a nurse, Miss Clara L. Masss and two
Spaniards. Another doctor was left with a fatal heart lesion and
one soldier left a helpless paralytic.
Guiteras 8 Cases & 3 deaths-

As further proof that the disease is transmitted solely by
the mosquito, Dr. R. P. Cook, of Winchester, Virginia and six
private soldiers remained for twenty days in a screened enclosure
where Yellow Fever patients had been kept. None became infected.
Three of them were later innoculated and quickly contracted the
disease.

Thus the last link in the chain was forged. Breeding places
of the mosquito were destroyed, and Cuba was rid of the Yellow
Fever plague that had existed in Havana for 150 years. It had
invaded the United States 90 times, causing a loss of thousands
of lives and millions of dollars. The more severe ravaged in
New Orleans, Charleston, Galveston, Portsmouth, Baltimore,
Philadelphia, New York and Memphis became history. It was an
enemy that in Portsmouth in 1855 took every third person.

Dr. Reed died in Washington, November 23, 1902 of appendicitis.
He lived to see his work accepted and plans made for important
work in this and various other allied lines. By his labors the
tropics were made safe, the Panama Canal made possible and the
canal zone, recognized as the most unhealthy place on earth, made
a health resort, with a death rate lower than Boston.

He laid the basis for such modern safeguards as the screen-
ing of houses, the protection of foodstuffs, the refrigeration of
meats, prompt chilling of milk and hundreds of other everyday
processes that save millions of lives annually all over the world.
